DataElement.preferredName: Surgical Margin Frozen Section Positive Finding Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether a thin slice of frozen tissue specimen cut from the edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery has cancer cells at the edge of the tissue.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Surgical Margin Frozen Section Positive Finding
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: infromation related to a thin slice of frozen tissue specimen cut from the edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery having cancer cells at the edge of the tissue.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.:An observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.

Concepts.definition: A thin slice of tissue cut from a frozen specimen, often used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.
A finding of abnormality following an examination or observation confirming something, such as the presence of a disease, condition, or microorganism.
